verses.text: A good name is to be chosen over great riches; favor is better than silver and gold.
verses.comment: This verse elevates character above material gain. In the spiritual sense, the value placed on a 'good name' echoes the importance of reputation among believers, and community discernment found throughout scripture. The preference for favor subtly points toward the honor given to saints and those who live virtuously.

verses.text: The rich and the poor meet together; the LORD is the maker of them all.
verses.comment: This verse teaches the equality of all people before God. Social status does not determine a person’s value in God’s sight. This affirmation of God's sovereignty anticipates the unity described in the New Testament Church, where all are one in Christ (Gal. 3:28).

verses.text: The prudent sees danger and hides himself, but the simple keep going and suffer for it.
verses.comment: Wisdom and discernment protect a person from evil. The imagery of hiding suggests seeking refuge, which spiritually can be interpreted as turning to God or the sacraments for protection in times of trial.

verses.text: The reward for humility and fear of the LORD is riches, honor, and life.
verses.comment: Humility and reverence for God bring blessings both temporal and eternal. This merges with New Testament teaching that humility precedes exaltation (Matt. 23:12), hinting at spiritual inheritance and the promise of eternal life.

verses.text: Thorns and traps are in the path of the crooked; whoever keeps his soul stays far from them.
verses.comment: The crooked path represents sinful living which leads to spiritual danger. Keeping one's soul, or guarding one’s heart, is a recurring biblical theme emphasizing the necessity of perseverance in faith and the spiritual disciplines.

verses.text: Train up a child in the way he should go; even when he is old he will not depart from it.
verses.comment: This emphasizes the importance of spiritual formation from youth. The verse resonates with the practice of catechesis, instructing children in faith so truth becomes lasting. It highlights continuity between generations in their walk with God.

verses.text: The rich rule over the poor, and the borrower is slave to the lender.
verses.comment: This verse delivers a practical warning about debt and power dynamics. Spiritually, it can be seen as a metaphor for the enslavement to sin and the freedom found in living according to God’s commands (Rom. 6:16).

verses.text: Whoever sows injustice will harvest trouble, and the rod of his anger will fail.
verses.comment: The law of sowing and reaping underscores divine justice. The reference to the ‘rod of anger’ also points to ultimate defeat of wickedness and victory for those who persevere in righteousness.

verses.text: The generous will be blessed, for they share their bread with the poor.
verses.comment: Charity as a path to blessing is a strong biblical theme. Sharing bread echoes acts of communion and reflects spiritual and corporal works of mercy throughout scripture.

verses.text: Drive out the mocker, and strife will leave; quarrels and insults will cease.
verses.comment: The removal of those who sow discord brings peace, echoing the call for purity and unity among the faithful. This sets a pattern for excommunication and the restoration of harmony.

verses.text: He who loves a pure heart and gracious speech will have the king as his friend.
verses.comment: Purity of heart and gracious speech are rewarded with royal favor. Symbolically, this points to the intimacy believers have with Christ, the true King (Rev. 19:16), and the importance of holy conversation.

verses.text: The eyes of the LORD protect knowledge, but he frustrates the words of the treacherous.
verses.comment: Divine providence safeguards true wisdom; those who oppose God’s truth are foiled. This assures believers of divine guidance in maintaining orthodox teaching.

verses.text: The sluggard says, “There is a lion outside! I will be killed in the streets!”
verses.comment: Laziness is exposed by excuses and irrational fears. Spiritually, such avoidance mirrors avoidance of spiritual duties and obligations, despite the challenges they present.

verses.text: The mouth of forbidden women is a deep pit; he with whom the LORD is angry will fall into it.
verses.comment: Sexual temptation leads to destruction, and is a form of judgment for rebellion. This underscores the gravity of sin and the necessity for grace and virtue to resist.

verses.text: Folly is bound up in the heart of a child, but the rod of discipline drives it far away.
verses.comment: Children need correction to overcome folly and grow in wisdom, highlighting the importance of parental guidance and faithful discipline.

verses.text: Whoever oppresses the poor to enrich himself, and whoever gives gifts to the rich, will both come to poverty.
verses.comment: Injustice to the poor and flattery to the rich lead to ruin. This affirms God's preferential concern for the poor and the dangers of social corruption.

verses.text: Incline your ear and hear the words of the wise, and set your heart on my knowledge.
verses.comment: Seeking wisdom intentionally is urged here. Spiritual attentiveness, or docility to the teachings of wise men, parallels listening to apostolic teaching.

verses.text: For it is pleasant if you keep them within you, and if all of them are ready on your lips.
verses.comment: The joy found in wisdom echoes the delight of meditating on God’s Word, both internal and external, as seen in the Psalms.

verses.text: So that your trust may be in the LORD, I teach you today, even you.
verses.comment: Wisdom leads to faith. The close connection between instruction and trust in God alludes to apostolic teaching guiding the faithful toward deeper faith.

verses.text: Have I not written for you thirty sayings of counsel and knowledge,
verses.comment: This verse refers to a structured collection of wise sayings, an early example of inspired tradition being passed down to believers.

verses.text: to show you true and reliable words, so that you may give a true answer to those who sent you?
verses.comment: This highlights the role of wisdom in apologetics—the defense of truth and providing reliable answers to others.

verses.text: Do not rob the poor because he is poor, nor crush the afflicted at the gate;
verses.comment: Protecting the vulnerable is a central biblical ethic, foreshadowing the social teachings in the New Testament (James 1:27).

verses.text: For the LORD will defend their cause and take the life of those who rob them.
verses.comment: Divine advocacy for the poor reinforces the seriousness of justice. This role as defender is echoed in depictions of God as judge.

verses.text: Do not make friends with a man given to anger, nor go with a hot-tempered man,
verses.comment: Guarding friendship is advised, as anger corrupts. Scripture often likens unchecked anger to spiritual disorder, which can spread within a community.

verses.text: lest you learn his ways and get yourself ensnared.
verses.comment: The danger of bad company leading to imitation is a common theme, again emphasizing the need for spiritual formation and wise counsel.

verses.text: Do not be one who gives pledges, who puts up security for debts.
verses.comment: The danger of financial entanglements is reiterated. This also touches on stewardship and prudence, which are key spiritual virtues.

verses.text: If you lack the means to pay, your bed will be taken from under you.
verses.comment: Being unable to repay debt leads to loss, connecting practical wisdom with social justice regulations found in the Law of Moses.

verses.text: Do not remove the ancient boundary stone set up by your forefathers.
verses.comment: Respect for ancestral boundaries encourages fidelity to tradition. At a deeper level, this admonition encourages deference to spiritual tradition preserved by the Church.

verses.text: Do you see a man skillful in his work? He will stand before kings; he will not stand before obscure men.
verses.comment: Skill and diligence are exalted here, promising honor even among the great, reminiscent of biblical figures raised up for their faithfulness. Harmonizes with the teaching that excellence in earthly vocation can lead to recognition and influence within God’s people.
